section.title: Nominal and Effective Interest Rates
section.p: The last activity focused on one important detail: when to value our cash flows. In the next three activities, we are going to focus on another important detail: which interest rate to use. We will see that this is intimately related to our choice of units for time. The most common error is probably using an interest rate that does not match our unit of time, so we will return to this throughout the first five chapters of this book.

As a starting point, we note that we are often quoted an interest rate for a year that is intended to be divided up evenly among natural subdivisions of the year (like months or quarters). This is called a nominal interest rate. It is essentially useless in calculations. It does not tell you what interest is actually earned. The interest rate we need for all of our calculations is called a effective interest rate. The effective interest rates tell us how much interest is accrued over a period of time.

assemblage.title: A Warning
assemblage.p: ⚠ In calculations, only use effective rates!.

section.p: Note that if we are already using \iota for an interest rate, and we need a different interest rate, we will use a different symbol. Often we go right to j. We will see others throughout this book.
In order to make the terms nominal and effective interest rates meaningful, we begin with an illustrative and relatively simple example.

introduction.p: We have an account earning 12% compounded monthly (sometimes just said monthly, or convertible monthly). This means that this 12% is split up evenly over the 12 months of the year.

task.p: What interest rate applies to a single month? This is the effective periodic rate (in this case, the effective monthly rate).
Suppose you invest $1 for a year. Sketch a timeline showing all of the interest that compounds. You can skip some months once you figure out a computational shortcut!
How much is in the account at the end of the year?
How much of that amount in the account is interest?
Express that as a percentage, which is a rate of interest for a year in this account. This is called the effective annual interest rate.
Why is your result different from the 12% annual rate we started with? (The 12% rate is called the nominal annual interest rate.)

section.p: Actuaries have their own notation for a nominal interest rate. An nominal interest rate compounded n times per year is denoted \iota^{(n)}. So, for example, in the last question you were given \iota^{(2)} = 0.075. The (n) is not an exponent, it is not an operation, it is simply a designation. That is why it is in parentheses - to distinguish it from an exponent.

You can be given a nominal rate that compounds less often than once per year: \iota^{(1/2)} would represent a nominal rate compounded every 2 years, so the 2-year effective rate is \iota^{(1/2)}/(1/2).

assemblage.title: 🧮Calculator Corner
assemblage.p: We can convert between nominal and effective annual rates in the calculator. To do so, locate and select the ICONV button (it is above the button for 2, so you will need the 2ND key). You will see an option for NOM. This is where you can enter or calculate a nominal annual rate. If you press the key, you will see an option for EFF. This is where you can enter or calculate an effective annual rate. If you press once more, you will see an option for C/Y. This is where you can enter how often interest is compounded per year.

The way this works is that you enter the two pieces of information you have (hit the ENTER key after each numerical entry), navigate to the quantity you want to calculate, and press the CPT key. All rates should be entered as percentages (i.e. 6, not .06).
